data.title: Around Town Store Closings By The Mccrory Corporation Will Mean Big Savings For Customers As The Retail Chain Discounts All Merchandise In The 300 Targeted Stores.
data.meta_description: Tuesday, January 28, 1997     Page: AROUND TOWN     Store closings by the McCrory Corporation will mean big savings for customers as the retail chain discounts all merchandise in the 300 targeted storesThe discounts will continue until all merchandise at those stores is sold.     The York-based retailer that has been operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy […]
data.text:
Tuesday, January 28, 1997 Page:

AROUND TOWN

Store closings by the McCrory Corporation will mean big savings for

customers as the retail chain discounts all merchandise in the 300 targeted

storesThe discounts will continue until all merchandise at those stores is

sold.

The York-based retailer that has been operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy

since 1992 announced a restructuring last week. The retailer operates under

the names McCrory, McLellan, H.L. Green, Silvers Store, J.J. Newberry, G.C.

Murphy, Coast to Coast, WM Tally House and Kress Store.

By Friday, sales will be in place at all 300 stores including:

J.J. Newberry Co., 28-34 N. Main St., Carbondale.

J.J. Newberry Co., 6-12 Independence St., Shamokin.

J.J. Newberry Co., 600 Main St., Stroudsburg.

McCrory Store, Sunbury Plaza, Sunbury.

Other McCrory Corporation stores in the Back Mountain Shopping Center,

Midway Shopping Center and Hazleton are not on the list of store closings.

Staffing at Tobyhanna Army Depot will remain at the current levels, federal

officials announced Thursday.

Previously, federal officials considered laying off 274 of the depot’s

2,462 employees, citing a decrease in the workload. But the U.S. Army

Industrial Operations Command has reviewed the work and the staffing level and

concluded that no change is needed.

Adult Services Unlimited, trading as Riverside Rehabilitation Center, of

Plains Township, and Health Poconos, of Mount Pocono, have been sold by Diane

Bartoli to Arbor Health Care Company of Lima, Ohio.

Both facilities provide general, job-related injury and geriatric

rehabilitation. They also offer specialty programs in pulmonary

rehabilitation, chronic pain management and arthritis rehabilitation.

In 1996, the combined facilities served more than 1,300 patients with more

than 12,000 visits. They had combined revenues of $2.8 million.

Frank A. Pugliese Jr., formerly administrator of Riverside Rehabilitation,

was named chief executive officer of the Plains Township facility. James S.

Crawford, vice president of outpatient rehabilitation, will manage both

facilities.

Arbor Health Care Co. provides subacute and complex medical services and

basic health care services for geriatric or chronically ill patients. The

company operates 30 licensed nursing centers with 3,578 beds in five states

and its Pharmacy Division serves 23,900 beds in Ohio and Florida.

NATION

Revco D.S. Inc. and CVS Corp. confirmed Monday that they were discussing a

possible merger, giving Revco stock a short-lived boost before the uncertainty

of the deal eroded most of the gains.

The joint statement said there was no certainty that the talks would lead

to a deal and that the two companies wouldn’t comment again until either the

talks end or there is an agreement.

News of the talks in Monday’s editions of The Wall Street Journal pushed

Revco’s stock up as much as 5 percent in the early minutes of trading. But

Revco later traded down 37.5 cents at $38.87 on the New York Stock Exchange.

The combination would create the nation’s No. 2 drugstore chain in terms of

sales behind Walgreen Co. and slightly ahead of Rite Aid Corp. Together, Revco

and CVS have about 4,000 stores and revenue of $11 billion.

Analysts said the deal makes sense because Revco and CVS are among the last

remaining major drug store chains not involved in a large merger. Such deals

are a way for drug stores to compete with large supermarket pharmacies and

mail-in prescription services.

Compaq Computer Corp. remained the world’s leading seller of personal

computers in 1996, a year in which the industry continued to grow but at a

slower rate than previously expected.

Analysts blamed delay of consumer purchases in the United States and

weakness in some overseas economies for the industry’s less-rapid pace.

Still, worldwide PC shipments rose 17.8 percent in 1996, according to

Dataquest Inc. of San Jose, Calif. Meanwhile, International Data Corp. of

Framingham, Mass., reported 16 percent growth.

Compaq enjoyed the No. 1 spot for the third consecutive year, followed by

IBM, Packard Bell-NEC, Apple and Hewlett-Packard, according to both IDC and

Dataquest. Hewlett-Packard experienced the fastest growth, seeing sales rise

48 percent according to IDC and 51.8 percent according to Dataquest.

Overall, the industry sold 68.4 million personal computers last year,

according to IDC. Dataquest’s figure was 70.9 million.
